"description": "You can't stop the future.

column12: almost

column20: and for
column21: himself. The pleasure he gives away
column22: or sets aside
column23: with all his heart. It is there for the reader who can handle it to keep.\nJ.D. Salinger's classic novel of teenage angst and rebellion was first published in 1951. The novel was included on Time's 2005 list of the 100 best English-language novels written since 1923. It was named by Modern Library and its readers as one of the 100 best English-language novels of the 20th century. It has been frequently challenged in the court for its liberal use of profanity and portrayal of sexuality and in the 1950's and 60's it was the novel that every teenage boy wants to read."}

column13: spiritual devotion
column14: and what she really wanted out of life.\nAround the time Elizabeth Gilbert turned thirty
column15: she went through an early-onslaught midlife crisis. She had everything an educated
column16: ambitious American woman was supposed to want--a husband
column17: a house
column18: a successful career. But instead of feeling happy and fulfilled
column19: she was consumed with panic
column20: grief
column21: and confusion. She went through a divorce
column22: a crushing depression
column23: another failed love
column24: and the eradication of everything she ever thought she was supposed to be.\nTo recover from all this
column25: Gilbert took a radical step. In order to give herself the time and space to find out who she really was and what she really wanted
column26: she got rid of her belongings
column27: quit her job
column28: and undertook a yearlong journey around the world--all alone. Eat
column29: Pray
column30: Love is the absorbing chronicle of that year. Her aim was to visit three places where she could examine one aspect of her own nature set against the backdrop of a culture that has traditionally done that one thing very well. In Rome
column31: she studied the art of pleasure
column32: learning to speak Italian and gaining the twenty-three happiest pounds of her life. India was for the art of devotion
column33: and with the help of a native guru and a surprisingly wise cowboy from Texas
column34: she embarked on four uninterrupted months of spiritual exploration. In Bali
column35: she studied the art of balance between worldly enjoyment and divine transcendence. She became the pupil of an elderly medicine man and also fell in love the best way--unexpectedly.\nAn intensely articulate and moving memoir of self-discovery
column38: Love is about what can happen when you claim responsibility for your own contentment and stop trying to live in imitation of society's ideals. It is certain to touch anyone who has ever woken up to the unrelenting need for change."}

column9: "description": "Andrew \"Ender\" Wiggin thinks he is playing computer simulated war games; he is

column8: "description": "A grumpy yet loveable man finds his solitary world turned on its head when a boisterous young family moves in next door.\nMeet Ove. He's a curmudgeon

column16: funny

column11: order and predictability shelter him from the messy
column12: wider world. Then
column13: at fifteen

"description": "I have a curse

column9: moving tale of unconditional love in a family that

column11: gave the author the fiery determination to carve out a successful life on her own terms.\nJeannette Walls grew up with parents whose ideals and stubborn nonconformity were both their curse and their salvation. Rex and Rose Mary Walls had four children. In the beginning

column8: "description": "The Lovely Bonesis the story of a family devastated by a gruesome murder -- a murder recounted by the teenage victim. Upsetting

column11: Susie Salmon describes how she was confronted by the murderer one December afternoon on her way home from school. Lured into an underground hiding place

column16: desperate for the killer to be found and punished.\nSebold creates a heaven that's calm and comforting

column18: and she intensely watches her family and friends as they struggle to cope with a reality in which she is no longer a part. To her great credit

column9: "description": "Harry Potter is due to start his fifth year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. His best friends Ron and Hermione have been very secretive all summer and he is desperate to get back to school and find out what has been going on. However

column3: "title": "Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival
column10: "description": "In her long-awaited new book
column11: Laura Hillenbrand writes with the same rich and vivid narrative voice she displayed in \u0001. Telling an unforgettable story of a man's journey into extremity
column12: Unbroken is a testament to the resilience of the human mind
column13: body
column14: and spirit.On a May afternoon in 1943
column15: an Army Air Forces bomber crashed into the Pacific Ocean and disappeared
column16: leaving only a spray of debris and a slick of oil
column17: gasoline
column18: and blood. Then
column19: on the ocean surface
column20: a face appeared. It was that of a young lieutenant
column21: the plane's bombardier
column22: who was struggling to a life raft and pulling himself aboard. So began one of the most extraordinary odysseys of the Second World War.The lieutenant's name was Louis Zamperini. In boyhood
column23: he'd been a cunning and incorrigible delinquent
column24: breaking into houses
column25: brawling
column26: and fleeing his home to ride the rails. As a teenager
column27: he had channeled his defiance into running
column28: discovering a prodigious talent that had carried him to the Berlin Olympics and within sight of the four-minute mile. But when war had come
column29: the athlete had become an airman
column30: embarking on a journey that led to his doomed flight
column31: a tiny raft
column32: and a drift into the unknown.\nAhead of Zamperini lay thousands of miles of open ocean
column39: a trial even greater. Driven to the limits of endurance
column40: Zamperini would answer desperation with ingenuity; suffering with hope
column42: and humor; brutality with rebellion. His fate
column44: would be suspended on the fraying wire of his will."}

column8: "description": "From Harper Lee comes a landmark new novel set two decades after her beloved Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece

column19: richer understanding and appreciation of Harper Lee. Here is an unforgettable novel of wisdom
column20: humanity
column21: passion
column22: humor and effortless precision--a profoundly affecting work of art that is both wonderfully evocative of another era and relevant to our own times. It not only confirms the enduring brilliance of To Kill a Mockingbird
column23: but also serves as its essential companion
column24: adding depth
column25: context and new meaning to an American classic."}

column8: "description": "Orphaned into the household of her Aunt Reed at Gateshead and subject to the cruel regime at Lowood charity school

column13: love
column14: sex
column15: booze

But the land of Quentin's fantasies turns out to be much darker and more dangerous than he could have imagined. His childhood dream becomes a nightmare with a shocking truth at its heart.\nAt once psychologically piercing and magnificently absorbing
column18: The Magicians boldly moves into uncharted literary territory

column3: "title": "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (Harry Potter
column9: "description": "The war against Voldemort is not going well: even Muggle governments are noticing. Ron scans the obituary pages of The Daily Prophet looking for familiar names. Dumbledore is absent from Hogwarts for long stretches of time

column15: potentially deadly

column3: "title": "To All the Boys I've Loved Before (To All the Boys I've Loved Before
column9: "description": "What if all the crushes you ever had found out how you felt about them... all at once?\nSixteen-year-old Lara Jean Song keeps her love letters in a hatbox her mother gave her. column11: because her letters are for her eyes only. Until the day her secret letters are mailed
column12: and suddenly
column13: Lara Jean's love life goes from imaginary to out of control."}

column17: but when they bring their findings to Mr. Penumbra

column16: despite her red blood

column8: "description": "Georgie McCool knows her marriage is in trouble; it has been in trouble for a long time. She still loves her husband

column13: and something's come up on her show; she has to stay in Los Angeles. She knows that Neal will be upset with her -- Neal is always a little upset with Georgie -- but she doesn't expect him to pack up the kids and go home without her.\nWhen her husband and the kids leave for the airport

column8: "description": "SOMETIMES THE ONE WHO LOVES YOU IS THE ONE WHO HURTS YOU THE MOST\nLily hasn't always had it easy

column13: stubborn
column14: and maybe even a little arrogant. He's also sensitive
column15: brilliant
column16: and has a total soft spot for Lily

column20: everything Lily has built with Ryle is threatened.\nWith this bold and deeply personal novel

column13:
as long as Tate can stick to the only two rules Miles has for her.

They think they can handle it
column14:
but realize almost immediately they can't handle it at all.

column9: "description": "The Expose\nMillenniumpublisher Mikael Blomkvist has made his reputation exposing corrupt establishment figures. So when a young journalist approaches him with an investigation into sex trafficking

The killer left the weapon at the scene - and the fingerprints on the gun point to only one direction.\nThe Girl Who Played with Fire\nEx-security analyst Lisbeth Salander is wanted for murder. Her history of unpredictable and vengeful behavior makes her an official danger to society - but no-one can find her. The only way Salander can be reached is by computer. But she can break into almost any network she chooses..."}

column3: "title": "The Wrath and the Dawn (The Wrath and the Dawn
column9: "description": "One Life to One Dawn.\nIn a land ruled by a murderous boy-king

column16: weaving stories that enchant

column19: Shahrzad finds herself falling in love. How is this possible? It's an unforgivable betrayal. Still

column21: despite her love
column22: be ready to take Khalid's life as retribution for the many lives he's stolen. Can their love survive this world of stories and secrets?"}

column9: I'm the guy who reads your e-mail

column11: I love you...\"\nBeth Fremont and Jennifer Scribner-Snyder know that somebody is monitoring their work e-mail. (Everybody in the newsroom knows. It's company policy.) But they can't quite bring themselves to take it seriously. They go on sending each other endless and endlessly hilarious e-mails

column13: Lincoln O'Neill can't believe this is his job now- reading other people's e-mail. When he applied to be \"internet security officer

column15: he knows he should turn them in. But he can't help being entertained-and captivated-by their stories.\nBy the time Lincoln realizes he's falling for Beth

column11: and Simon.\nWhat price is too high to pay

column9: astonishing in scope
column10: and impossible to put down
column11: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks captures the beauty and drama of scientific discovery
column12: as well as its human consequences.Her name was Henrietta Lacks
column13: but scientists know her as HeLa. She was a poor Southern tobacco farmer who worked the same land as her slave ancestors
column14: yet her cells--taken without her knowledge--became one of the most important tools in medicine. The first \"immortal\" human cells grown in culture
column15: they are still alive today
column16: though she has been dead for more than sixty years. If you could pile all HeLa cells ever grown onto a scale
column17: they'd weigh more than 50 million metric tons--as much as a hundred Empire State Buildings. HeLa cells were vital for developing the polio vaccine; uncovered secrets of cancer
column18: viruses
column19: and the atom bomb's effects; helped lead to important advances like in vitro fertilization
column20: cloning
column21: and gene mapping; and have been bought and sold by the billions.Yet Henrietta Lacks remains virtually unknown
column22: buried in an unmarked grave.\nNow Rebecca Skloot takes us on an extraordinary journey
column23: from the \"colored\" ward of Johns Hopkins Hospital in the 1950s to stark white laboratories with freezers full of HeLa cells; from Henrietta's small
column24: dying hometown of Clover
column25: Virginia -- a land of wooden slave quarters
column26: faith healings
column27: and voodoo -- to East Baltimore today
column28: where her children and grandchildren live and struggle with the legacy of her cells.\nHenrietta's family did not learn of her \"immortality\" until more than twenty years after her death
column29: when scientists investigating HeLa began using her husband and children in research without informed consent. And though the cells had launched a multimillion-dollar industry that sells human biological materials
column30: her family never saw any of the profits. As Rebecca Skloot so brilliantly shows
column31: the story of the Lacks family -- past and present -- is inextricably connected to the dark history of experimentation on African Americans
column32: the birth of bioethics
column33: and the legal battles over whether we control the stuff we are made of.\nOver the decade it took to uncover this story
column34: Rebecca became enmeshed in the lives of the Lacks family--especially Henrietta's daughter Deborah
column35: who was devastated to learn about her mother's cells. She was consumed with questions: Had scientists cloned her mother? Did it hurt her when researchers infected her cells with viruses and shot them into space? What happened to her sister
column37: who died in a mental institution at the age of fifteen? And if her mother was so important to medicine
column38: why couldn't her children afford health insurance?\nIntimate in feeling
column41: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lackscaptures the beauty and drama of scientific discovery
column42: as well as its human consequences."}

column9:
"description": "Solving the Maze was supposed to be the end. 
Thomas was sure that escape from the Maze would mean freedom for him and the Gladers. But WICKED isn't done yet. Phase Two has just begun. The Scorch.
There are no rules. There is no help. You either make it or you die.
The Gladers have two weeks to cross through the Scorch--the most burned-out section of the world. And WICKED has made sure to adjust the variables and stack the odds against them.
Friendships will be tested. Loyalties will be broken. All bets are off. 
There are others now. Their survival depends on the Gladers' destruction--and they're determined to survive."}

column14: and does all the talking for both of them.\nYears later

column9: New York Timesbestselling author Lauren Oliver emerged as one of today's foremost authors of young adult fiction. Like Jay Asher's Thirteen Reasons Whyand Gayle Forman's If I Stay

column11: death

column20: Barnes & Noble
column21: The Daily Beast

column23: and Publishers Weekly. It has been optioned for film by Fox 2000 Pictures.\nSupports the Common Core State Standards."}

column3: "title": "World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War"
column8: "description": "The Zombie War came unthinkably close to eradicating humanity. Max Brooks
column9: driven by the urgency of preserving the acid-etched first-hand experiences of the survivors from those apocalyptic years
column10: traveled across the United States of America and throughout the world
column11: from decimated cities that once teemed with upwards of thirty million souls to the most remote and inhospitable areas of the planet. He recorded the testimony of men
column12: women
column13: and sometimes children who came face-to-face with the living
column14: or at least the undead
column15: hell of that dreadful time. \"World War Z\" is the result. Never before have we had access to a document that so powerfully conveys the depth of fear and horror
column16: and also the ineradicable spirit of resistance
column17: that gripped human society through the plague years.\nRanging from the now infamous village of New Dachang in the United Federation of China
column18: where the epidemiological trail began with the twelve-year-old Patient Zero
column19: to the unnamed northern forests where untold numbers sought a terrible and temporary refuge in the cold
column20: to the United States of Southern Africa
column21: where the Redeker Plan provided hope for humanity at an unspeakable price
column22: to the west-of-the-Rockies redoubt where the North American tide finally started to turn
column23: this invaluable chronicle reflects the full scope and duration of the Zombie War.\nMost of all
column24: the book captures with haunting immediacy the human dimension of this epochal event. Facing the often raw and vivid nature of these personal accounts requires a degree of courage on the part of the reader
column25: but the effort is invaluable because
column26: as Mr. Brooks says in his introduction
column27: \"By excluding the human factor
column28: aren't we risking the kind of personal detachment from history that may
column29: heaven forbid
column30: lead us one day to repeat it? And in the end
column31: isn't the human factor the only true difference between us and the enemy we now refer to as 'the living dead'?\"\nNote: Some of the numerical and factual material contained in this edition was previously published under the auspices of the United Nations Postwar Commission. Eyewitness reports from the first truly global war>"}

column9: "description": "\"I live for the dream that my children will be born free
column10: \" she says. \"That they will be what they like. That they will own the land their father gave them.\"\n\"I live for you
column11: \" I say sadly.\nEo kisses my cheek. \"Then you must live for more.\"\nDarrow is a Red
column12: a member of the lowest caste in the color-coded society of the future. Like his fellow Reds
column13: he works all day
column14: believing that he and his people are making the surface of Mars livable for future generations.\nYet he spends his life willingly
column15: knowing that his blood and sweat will one day result in a better world for his children.\nBut Darrow and his kind have been betrayed. Soon he discovers that humanity already reached the surface generations ago. Vast cities and sprawling parks spread across the planet. Darrow--and Reds like him--are nothing more than slaves to a decadent ruling class.\nInspired by a longing for justice
column16: and driven by the memory of lost love
column17: Darrow sacrifices everything to infiltrate the legendary Institute
column18: a proving ground for the dominant Gold caste
column19: where the next generation of humanity's overlords struggle for power. He will be forced to compete for his life and the very future of civilization against the best and most brutal of Society's ruling class. There
column20: he will stop at nothing to bring down his enemies... even if it means he has to become one of them to do so."}

column8: "description": "Fresh from a brief stay at a psych hospital
column9: reporter Camille Preaker faces a troubling assignment: she must return to her tiny hometown to cover the murders of two preteen girls. For years
column10: Camille has hardly spoken to her neurotic
column11: hypochondriac mother or to the half-sister she barely knows
column12: a beautiful thirteen-year-old with an eerie grip on the town. Now

column14: Camille finds herself identifying with the young victims--a bit too strongly. Dogged by her own demons
column15: she must unravel the psychological puzzle of her own past if she wants to get the story--and survive this homecoming."}

column9: "description": "WHAT IS LOST...\nWILL BE FOUND\nIn this stunning follow-up to the global phenomenon The Da Vinci Code
column10: Dan Brown demonstrates once again why he is the world's most popular thriller writer. The Lost Symbolis a masterstroke of storytelling - a deadly race through a real-world labyrinth of codes
column11: secrets
column12: and unseen truths...all under the watchful eye of Brown's most terrifying villain to date. Set within the hidden chambers
column13: tunnels
column14: and temples of Washington
column15: DC.
column16: The Lost Symbolaccelerates through a startling landscape toward an unthinkable finale.\nAs the story opens
column17: Harvard symbologist Robert Langdon is summoned unexpectedly to deliver an evening lecture in the U.S. Capitol Building. Within minutes of his arrival
column18: however
column19: the night takes a bizarre turn. A disturbing object - artfully encoded with five symbols - is discovered in the Capitol Building. Langdon recognizes the object as an ancient invitation...one meant to usher its recipient into a long-lost world of esoteric wisdom.\nWhen Langdon's beloved mentor
column20: Peter Solomon - a prominent Mason and philanthropist - is brutally kidnapped
column21: Langdon realizes his only hope of saving Peter is to accept this mystical invitation and follow wherever it leads him. Langdon is instantly into a clandestine world of Masonic secrets
column22: hidden history
column23: and never-before-seen locations - all of which seem to be dragging him toward a single
column24: inconceivable truth.\nAs the world discovered in The Da Vinci Codeand Angels & Demons
column25: Dan Brown's novels are brilliant tapestries of veiled histories
column26: arcane symbols
column27: and enigmatic codes. In this new novel
column28: he again challenges readers with an intelligent
column29: lightning-paced story that offers surprises at every turn. The Lost Symbolis exactly what Brown's fans have been waiting for...his most thrilling novel yet."}

column9: "description": "A compulsively readable and touching novel about misplaced genius and a mother and daughter's role in an absurd world.\nBernadette Fox is notorious. To her Microsoft-guru husband
column10: she's a fearlessly opinionated partner; to fellow private-school mothers in Seattle
column11: she's a disgrace; to design mavens
column12: she's a revolutionary architect
column13: and to 15-year-old Bee
column14: she is a best friend and
column15: simply
column16: Mom.\nThen Bernadette disappears. It began when Bee aced her report card and claimed her promised reward: a family trip to Antarctica. But Bernadette's intensifying allergy to Seattle - and people in general - has made her so agoraphobic that a virtual assistant in India now runs her most basic errands. A trip to the end of the earth is problematic.\nTo find her mother
column17: Bee compiles email messages
column18: official documents
column19: secret correspondence - creating a compulsively readable and touching novel about misplaced genius and a mother and daughter's role in an absurd world."}

column3: "title": "A Dance with Dragons (A Song of Ice and Fire

column3: "title": "The Art of Racing in the Rain"
column8: "description": "Enzo knows he is different from other dogs: a philosopher with a nearly human soul (and an obsession with opposable thumbs)
column9: he has educated himself by watching television extensively
column10: and by listening very closely to the words of his master

column12: an up-and-coming race car driver.\nThrough Denny
column13: Enzo has gained tremendous insight into the human condition
column14: and he sees that life
column15: like racing
column16: isn't simply about going fast. On the eve of his death
column17: Enzo takes stock of his life
column18: recalling all that he and his family have been through.\nA heart-wrenching but deeply funny and ultimately uplifting story of family
column19: love
column20: loyalty
column21: and hope
column22: The Art of Racing in the Rainis a beautifully crafted and captivating look at the wonders and absurdities of human life...as only a dog could tell it."}

column8: "description": "A tale of deceptive simplicity that slowly reveals an extraordinary emotional depth and resonance - and takes its place among Kazuo Ishiguro's finest work.\nFrom the acclaimed author of The Remains of the Day and When We Were Orphans
column9: a moving new novel that subtly re-imagines our world and time in a haunting story of friendship and love.\nAs a child
column10: Kathy-now thirty-one years old-lived at Hailsham
column11: a private school in the scenic English countryside where the children were sheltered from the outside world
column12: brought up to believe that they were special and that their well-being was crucial not only for themselves but for the society they would eventually enter. Kathy had long ago put this idyllic past behind her
column13: but when two of her Hailsham friends come back into her life
column14: she stops resisting the pull of memory.\nAnd so
column15: as her friendship with Ruth is rekindled
column16: and as the feelings that long ago fueled her adolescent crush on Tommy begin to deepen into love
column17: Kathy recalls their years at Hailsham. She describes happy scenes of boys and girls growing up together
column18: unperturbed-even comforted-by their isolation. But she describes other scenes as well: of discord and misunderstanding that hint at a dark secret behind Hailsham's nurturing facade. With the dawning clarity of hindsight
column19: the three friends are compelled to face the truth about their childhood-and about their lives now.\nA tale of deceptive simplicity
column20: Never Let Me Go slowly reveals an extraordinary emotional depth and resonance-and takes its place among Kazuo Ishiguro's finest work."}

column3: "title": "A Feast for Crows (A Song of Ice and Fire
column9: "description": "Alternate covers can be found \u0001.\nWith A Feast for Crows
column10: Martin delivers the long-awaited fourth volume of the landmark series that has redefined imaginative fiction and stands as a modern masterpiece in the making.\nAfter centuries of bitter strife

column12: outlaws
column13: renegades
column14: and carrion eaters of the Seven Kingdoms gather. Now
column15: as the human crows assemble over a banquet of ashes

column17: others only just appearing--emerge from an ominous twilight of past struggles and chaos to take up the challenges of the terrible times ahead. Nobles and commoners
column18: soldiers and sorcerers
column19: assassins and sages
column20: are coming together to stake their fortunes...and their lives. For at a feast for crows
column21: many are the guests--but only a few are the survivors."}

column8: "description": "Mindy Kaling has lived many lives: the obedient child of immigrant professionals
column9: a timid chubster afraid of her own bike
column10: a Ben Affleck-impersonating Off-Broadway performer and playwright
column11: and
column12: finally
column13: a comedy writer and actress prone to starting fights with her friends and coworkers with the sentence \"Can I just say one last thing about this
column14: and then I swear I'll shut up about it?\"\nPerhaps you want to know what Mindy thinks makes a great best friend (someone who will fill your prescription in the middle of the night)
column15: or what makes a great guy (one who is aware of all elderly people in any room at any time and acts accordingly)
column16: or what is the perfect amount of fame (so famous you can never get convicted of murder in a court of law)
column17: or how to maintain a trim figure (you will not find that information in these pages). If so

column20: Mindy invites readers on a tour of her life and her unscientific observations on romance
column21: friendship
column22: and Hollywood
column23: with several conveniently placed stopping points for you to run errands and make phone calls. Mindy Kaling really is just a Girl Next Door--not so much literally anywhere in the continental United States
column24: but definitely if you live in India or Sri Lanka."}

column9: "description": "Days before his release from prison
column10: Shadow's wife
column11: Laura
column12: dies in a mysterious car crash. Numbly
column13: he makes his way back home. On the plane
column14: he encounters the enigmatic Mr Wednesday
column15: who claims to be a refugee from a distant war
column16: a former god and the king of America.\nTogether they embark on a profoundly strange journey across the heart of the USA
column17: whilst all around them a storm of preternatural and epic proportions threatens to break.\nScary
column18: gripping and deeply unsettling
column19: American Godstakes a long

column21: never before published in the UK
column22: and is about 12
column23: 000 words longer than the previous UK edition."}

column9: "description": "It's the end of the line.\nWICKED has taken everything from Thomas: his life
column10: his memories
column11: and now his only friends--the Gladers. But it's finally over. The trials are complete
column12:
after one final test.
Will anyone survive?
What WICKED doesn't know is that Thomas remembers far more than they think. And it's enough to prove that he can't believe a word of what they say.
The truth will be terrifying.
Thomas beat the Maze. He survived the Scorch. He'll risk anything to save his friends. But the truth might be what ends it all.
The time for lies is over."}

column8: "description": "You can find the redesigned cover of this edition \u0001.\nWuthering Heights is a wild

column10: a foundling adopted by Catherine's father. After Mr Earnshaw's death
column11: Heathcliff is bullied and humiliated by Catherine's brother Hindley and wrongly believing that his love for Catherine is not reciprocated
column12: leaves Wuthering Heights
column13: only to return years later as a wealthy and polished man. He proceeds to exact a terrible revenge for his former miseries. The action of the story is chaotic and unremittingly violent
column14: but the accomplished handling of a complex structure
column15: the evocative descriptions of the lonely moorland setting and the poetic grandeur of vision combine to make this unique novel a masterpiece of English literature."}

column9: The Little Prince is the most translated book in the French language. With a timeless charm it tells the story of a little boy who leaves the safety of his own tiny planet to travel the universe

column3: "title": "A Court of Wings and Ruin (A Court of Thorns and Roses

column13: the earth will be painted red as mighty armies grapple for power over the one thing that could destroy them all."}

column9: The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry is an unforgettable tale of transformation and second chances
column10: an irresistible affirmation of why we read
column11:
and why we love.
We are not quite novels.
We are not quite short stories.
In the end
column12: we are collected works.\nA. J. Fikry's life is not at all what he expected it to be. His wife has died; his bookstore is experiencing the worst sales in its history; and now his prized possession
column13: a rare collection of Poe poems
column14: has been stolen. Slowly but surely
column15: he is isolating himself from all the people of Alice Island--from Chief Lambiase
column16: the well-intentioned police officer who's always felt kindly toward him; from Ismay
column17: his sister-in-law

column20: refusing to be deterred by A.J.'s bad attitude. Even the books in his store have stopped holding pleasure for him. These days
column21: he can only see them as a sign of a world that is changing too rapidly.\nAnd then a mysterious package appears at the bookstore. It's a small package
column22: though large in weight--an unexpected arrival that gives A.J. the opportunity to make his life over
column23: the ability to see everything anew. It doesn't take long for the locals to notice the change overcoming A.J.

column9: but she might as well be. By age thirteen

column9: "description": "In a kingdom by the sea...\nIn a secret world where half-angel warriors are sworn to fight demons
column10: parabataiis a sacred word.\nA parabataiis your partner in battle. A parabataiis your best friend. Parabataican be everything to each other--but they can never fall in love.\nEmma Carstairs is a warrior

column16: and faeries--the most powerful of supernatural creatures--teeter on the edge of open war with Shadowhunters. When the bodies of humans and faeries turn up murdered in the same way Emma's parents were when she was a child
column17: an uneasy alliance is formed. This is Emma's chance for revenge--and Julian's chance to get back his brother Mark

column20: and Julian have to do is solve the murders within two weeks...and before the murderer targets them.\nTheir search takes Emma from sea caves full of sorcery to a dark lottery where death is dispensed. And each clue she unravels uncovers more secrets. What has Julian been hiding from her all these years? Why does Shadowhunter Law forbid parabataito fall in love? Who really killed her parents--and can she bear to know the truth?\nThe darkly magical world of Shadowhunters has captured the imaginations of millions of readers across the globe. Join the adventure in Lady Midnight

column8: "description": "Melanie is a very special girl. Dr. Caldwell calls her \"our little genius.\"\nEvery morning

She tells her favorite teacher all the things she'll do when she grows up. Melanie doesn't know why this makes Miss Justineau look sad.\nThe Girl with All the Giftsis a sensational thriller
column12: perfect for fans of Stephen King
column13: Justin Cronin
column14: and Neil Gaiman."}

column8: "description": "\"Our Dragon doesn't eat the girls he takes

column14: and we're grateful

column16: her quiet village

column18: full of malevolent power
column19: and its shadow lies over her life.\nHer people rely on the cold

column23: graceful
column24: brave Kasia

column3: "title": "A Clash of Kings  (A Song of Ice and Fire
column9: "description": "Alternate cover edition can be found \u0001.\nTime is out of joint. The summer of peace and plenty

column11: is drawing to a close
column12: and the harsh
column13: chill winter approaches like an angry beast. Two great leaders--Lord Eddard Stark and Robert Baratheon--who held sway over an age of enforced peace are dead...victims of royal treachery. Now
column14: from the ancient citadel of Dragonstone to the forbidding shores of Winterfell

column20: the heir apparent

column22: victim of the scheming courtiers who teem over King's Landing. Robert's two brothers each seek their own dominion

column36: A Clash of Kings is a novel of dazzling beauty and boundless enchantment;a tale of pure excitement you will never forget."}

column9: "description": "Tally is about to turn sixteen
column10: and she can't wait. In just a few weeks she'll have the operation that will turn her from a repellent ugly into a stunning pretty. And as a pretty
column11: she'll be catapulted into a high-tech paradise where her only job is to have fun.\nBut Tally's new friend Shay isn't sure she wants to become a pretty. When Shay runs away
column12: Tally learns about a whole new side of the pretty world-- and it isn't very pretty. The authorities offer Tally a choice: find her friend and turn her in
column13: or never turn pretty at all. Tally's choice will change her world forever..."}

column8: "description": "What if you could live again and again
column9: until you got it right?\nOn a cold and snowy night in 1910
column10: Ursula Todd is born to an English banker and his wife. She dies before she can draw her first breath. On that same cold and snowy night
column11: Ursula Todd is born
column12: lets out a lusty wail
column13: and embarks upon a life that will be
column14: to say the least
column15: unusual. For as she grows
column16: she also dies
column17: repeatedly
column18: in a variety of ways
column19: while the young century marches on towards its second cataclysmic world war.\nDoes Ursula's apparently infinite number of lives give her the power to save the world from its inevitable destiny? And if she can - will she?\nDarkly comic
column20: startlingly poignant
column21: and utterly original - this is Kate Atkinson at her absolute best."}

column9: "description": "Every day a different body. Every day a different life. Every day in love with the same girl.\nThere's never any warning about where it will be or who it will be. A has made peace with that
column10: even established guidelines by which to live: Never get too attached. Avoid being noticed. Do not interfere.\nIt's all fine until the morning that A wakes up in the body of Justin and meets Justin's girlfriend
column11: Rhiannon. From that moment
column12: the rules by which A has been living no longer apply. Because finally A has found someone he wants to be with--day in
column13: day out
column14: day after day."}

column8: "description": "Sixteen-year-old Starr Carter moves between two worlds: the poor neighborhood where she lives and the fancy suburban prep school she attends. The uneasy balance between these worlds is shattered when Starr witnesses the fatal shooting of her childhood best friend Khalil at the hands of a police officer. Khalil was unarmed.\nSoon afterward
column9: his death is a national headline. Some are calling him a thug
column10: maybe even a drug dealer and a gangbanger. Protesters are taking to the streets in Khalil's name. Some cops and the local drug lord try to intimidate Starr and her family. What everyone wants to know is: what reallywent down that night? And the only person alive who can answer that is Starr.\nBut what Starr does or does not say could upend her community. It could also endanger her life."}

column3: "title": "The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (Millennium

column10: a bullet wound to her head

column13: journalist Mikael Blomkvist
column14: she will not only have to prove her innocence
column15: but also identify and denounce those in authority who have allowed the vulnerable
column16: like herself
column17: to suffer abuse and violence. And
column18: on her own
column19: she will plot revenge - against the man who tried to kill her
column20: and the corrupt government institutions that very nearly destroyed her life.\nOnce upon a time
column21: she was a victim. Now Salander is fighting back.\n~from the jacket"}

column9: Missy
column10: has been abducted during a family vacation

column12: \"Mack receives a suspicious note

What he finds there will change Mack's world forever.\nIn a world where religion seems to grow increasingly irrelevant The Shackwrestles with the timeless question

column8:

I'm definitely not the kind of girl who meets a cute boy on a crowded New York City street and falls in love with him. Not when my family is twelve hours away from being deported to Jamaica. Falling in love with him won't be my story.\nDaniel: I've always been the good son

column3: "title": "Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking"
column8: "description": "At least one-third of the people we know are introverts. They are the ones who prefer listening to speaking
column9: reading to partying; who innovate and create but dislike self-promotion; who favor working on their own over brainstorming in teams. Although they are often labeled \"quiet
column10: \" it is to introverts that we owe many of the great contributions to society--from van Gogh's sunflowers to the invention of the personal computer.\nPassionately argued
column11: impressively researched
column12: and filled with indelible stories of real people
column13: Quiet shows how dramatically we undervalue introverts
column14: and how much we lose in doing so. Taking the reader on a journey from Dale Carnegie's birthplace to Harvard Business School
column15: from a Tony Robbins seminar to an evangelical megachurch
column16: Susan Cain charts the rise of the Extrovert Ideal in the twentieth century and explores its far-reaching effects. She talks to Asian-American students who feel alienated from the brash
column17: backslapping atmosphere of American schools. She questions the dominant values of American business culture
column18: where forced collaboration can stand in the way of innovation
column19: and where the leadership potential of introverts is often overlooked. And she draws on cutting-edge research in psychology and neuroscience to reveal the surprising differences between extroverts and introverts.\nPerhaps most inspiring
column20: she introduces us to successful introverts--from a witty
column21: high-octane public speaker who recharges in solitude after his talks
column22: to a record-breaking salesman who quietly taps into the power of questions. Finally
column23: she offers invaluable advice on everything from how to better negotiate differences in introvert-extrovert relationships to how to empower an introverted child to when it makes sense to be a \"pretend extrovert.\"\nThis extraordinary book has the power to permanently change how we see introverts and
column24: equally important
column25: how introverts see themselves."}

column8: "description": "Kurt Vonnegut's absurdist classic Slaughterhouse-Fiveintroduces us to Billy Pilgrim
column9: a man who becomes unstuck in time after he is abducted by aliens from the planet Tralfamadore. In a plot-scrambling display of virtuosity
column10: we follow Pilgrim simultaneously through all phases of his life
column11: concentrating on his (and Vonnegut's) shattering experience as an American prisoner of war who witnesses the firebombing of Dresden.\nDon't let the ease of reading fool you - Vonnegut's isn't a conventional
column12: or simple
column13: novel. He writes
column14: \"There are almost no characters in this story
column15: and almost no dramatic confrontations
column16: because most of the people in it are so sick
column17: and so much the listless playthings of enormous forces. One of the main effects of war
column18: after all
column19: is that people are discouraged from being characters.\"\nSlaughterhouse-Fiveis not only Vonnegut's most powerful book
column20: it is also as important as any written since 1945. Like Catch- 22
column21: it fashions the author's experiences in the Second World War into an eloquent and deeply funny plea against butchery in the service of authority. Slaughterhouse-Fiveboasts the same imagination
column22: humanity
column23: and gleeful appreciation of the absurd found in Vonnegut's other works

column25: tragic fact gives it a unique poignancy - and humor."}

column18: at last

column15: Of Mice and Menhas proved one of Steinbeck's most popular works

column3: "title": "On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft"
column8: "description": "On Writing begins with King's childhood and his uncannily early focus on writing to tell a story. King next turns to the basic tools of his trade and culminates with a profoundly moving account of how King's overwhelming need to write spurred him toward recovery.\n\"If you don't have the time to read
column9: you don't have the time or the tools to write.\"\nIn 1999
column10: Stephen King began to write about his craft -- and his life. By midyear
column11: a widely reported accident jeopardized the survival of both. And in his months of recovery
column12: the link between writing and living became more crucial than ever.\nRarely has a book on writing been so clear
column13: so useful
column14: and so revealing. On Writing begins with a mesmerizing account of King's childhood and his uncannily early focus on writing to tell a story. A series of vivid memories from adolescence
column15: college
column16: and the struggling years that led up to his first novel
column17: Carrie
column18: will afford readers a fresh and often very funny perspective on the formation of a writer. King next turns to the basic tools of his trade -- how to sharpen and multiply them through use
column19: and how the writer must always have them close at hand. He takes the reader through crucial aspects of the writer's art and life

column22: with new story material
column23: in addition to a new introduction and foreword. It also includes four full-color illustrations in the hardcover and trade paperback formats."}

column9: "description": "I didn't ask for any of this. I didn't ask to be some kind of hero.\nBut when your whole life gets swept up by a tornado - taking you with it - you have no choice but to go along
column10: you know?\nSure
column11: I've read the books. I've seen the movies. I know the song about the rainbow and the happy little bluebirds. But I never expected Oz to look like this. To be a place where Good Witches can't be trusted
column12: Wicked Witches may just be the good guys
column13:
and winged monkeys can be executed for acts of rebellion. There's still a yellow brick road - but even that's crumbling.
What happened? Dorothy.
They say she found a way to come back to Oz. They say she seized power and the power went to her head. And now no one is safe.
My name is Amy Gumm - and I'm the other girl from Kansas.
I've been recruited by the Revolutionary Order of the Wicked.
I've been trained to fight.
And I have a mission."}

column8: "description": "Zack Lightman has spent his life dreaming. Dreaming that the real world could be a little more like the countless science-fiction books
column9: movies
column10: and videogames he's spent his life consuming. Dreaming that one day
column11: some fantastic
column12: world-altering event will shatter the monotony of his humdrum existence and whisk him off on some grand space-faring adventure.\nBut hey
column13: there's nothing wrong with a little escapism
column14: right? After all
column15: Zack tells himself
column16: he knows the difference between fantasy and reality. He knows that here in the real world
column17: aimless teenage gamers with anger issues don't get chosen to save the universe.\nAnd then he sees the flying saucer.\nEven stranger
column18: the alien ship he's staring at is straight out of the videogame he plays every night
column19: a hugely popular online flight simulator called Armada--in which gamers just happen to be protecting the earth from alien invaders.\nNo
column20: Zack hasn't lost his mind. As impossible as it seems
column21: what he's seeing is all too real. And his skills--as well as those of millions of gamers across the world--are going to be needed to save the earth from what's about to befall it.\nIt's Zack's chance
column22: at last

column25: and wondering: Doesn't something about this scenario seem a little...familiar?\nAt once gleefully embracing and brilliantly subverting science-fiction conventions as only Ernest Cline could
column26: Armadais a rollicking
column27: surprising thriller
column28: a classic coming of age adventure
column29: and an alien invasion tale like nothing you've ever read before--one whose every page is infused with the pop-culture savvy that has helped make Ready Player Onea phenomenon."}

column8: "description": "College student Devin Jones took the summer job at Joyland hoping to forget the girl who broke his heart. But he wound up facing something far more terrible: the legacy of a vicious murder
column9: the fate of a dying child
column10: and dark truths about life--and what comes after--that would change his world forever.\nA riveting story about love and loss
column11: about growing up and growing old--and about those who don't get to do either because death comes for them before their time--Joylandis Stephen King at the peak of his storytelling powers. With all of the emotional impact of King masterpieces such as The Green Mileand The Shawshank Redemption
column12: Joylandis at once a mystery
column13: a horror story
column14: and a bittersweet coming-of-age novel
column15: one that will leave even the most hard-boiled reader profoundly moved."}

column8: "description": "Cora is a slave on a cotton plantation in Georgia. Life is hellish for all the slaves but especially bad for Cora; an outcast even among her fellow Africans
column9: she is coming into womanhood - where even greater pain awaits. When Caesar
column10: a recent arrival from Virginia
column11: tells her about the Underground Railroad
column12: they decide to take a terrifying risk and escape. Matters do not go as planned and
column13: though they manage to find a station and head north
column14: they are being hunted.\nIn Whitehead's ingenious conception
column15: the Underground Railroad is no mere metaphor - engineers and conductors operate a secret network of tracks and tunnels beneath the Southern soil. Cora and Caesar's first stop is South Carolina
column16: in a city that initially seems like a haven - but the city's placid surface masks an insidious scheme designed for its black denizens. Even worse: Ridgeway
column17: the relentless slave catcher
column18: is close on their heels. Forced to flee again
column19: Cora embarks on a harrowing flight
column20: state by state
column21: seeking true freedom.\nAs Whitehead brilliantly re-creates the unique terrors for black people in the pre-Civil War era
column22: his narrative seamlessly weaves the saga of America from the brutal importation of Africans to the unfulfilled promises of the present day. The Underground Railroadis at once a kinetic adventure tale of one woman's ferocious will to escape the horrors of bondage and a shattering
column23: powerful meditation on the history we all share."}

column3: "title": "The Bad Beginning (A Series of Unfortunate Events
column9: "description": "Dear Reader
column10: \nI'm sorry to say that the book you are holding in your hands is extremely unpleasant. It tells an unhappy tale about three very unlucky children. Even though they are charming and clever
column11: the Baudelaire siblings lead lives filled with misery and woe. From the very first page of this book when the children are at the beach and receive terrible news
column12: continuing on through the entire story
column13: disaster lurks at their heels. One might say they are magnets for misfortune.\nIn this short book alone
column14: the three youngsters encounter a greedy and repulsive villain
column15: itchy clothing
column16: a disastrous fire
column17: a plot to steal their fortune
column18: and cold porridge for breakfast.\nIt is my sad duty to write down these unpleasant tales
column19: but there is nothing stopping you from putting this book down at once and reading something happy
column20: if you prefer that sort of thing.\nWith all due respect
column21: \nLemony Snicket"}

column8: "description": "It is the story of an old Cuban fisherman and his supreme ordeal: a relentless

column10: powerful language of a fable

column23: between a past he's tried to bury and a future he cannot conceive.\nAward-winning author William Landay has written the consummate novel of an embattled family in crisis - a suspenseful
column24: character-driven mystery that is also a spellbinding tale of guilt
column25: betrayal

column9: "description": "Speak again the ancient oaths
column10:
Life before death.

column8: "description": "Berlin 1942\nWhen Bruno returns home from school one day

column3: "title": "The Five People You Meet in Heaven"
column8: "description": "From the author of Tuesdays with Morrie
column9: a novel that explores the unexpected connections of our lives

column11: a novel that explores the unexpected connections of our lives
column12: and the idea that heaven is more than a place; it's an answer.\nEddie is a wounded war veteran
column13: an old man who has lived
column14: in his mind

column8: "description": "This is the way the world ends: with a nanosecond of computer error in a Defense Department laboratory and a million casual contacts that form the links in a chain letter of death.\nAnd here is the bleak new world of the day after: a world stripped of its institutions and emptied of 99 percent of its people. A world in which good rides on the frail shoulders of the 108-year-old Mother Abigail and the worst nightmares of evil are embodied in a man with a lethal smile and unspeakable powers: Randall Flagg
column9: the dark man."}
gripping
column10: at once darkly funny and tender
column11: spanning three continents and numerous lives

column8: "description": "What happens when the most beautiful girl in the world marries the handsomest prince of all time and he turns out to be...well...a lot less than the man of her dreams?\nAs a boy

He's reconstructed the \"Good Parts Version\" to delight wise kids and wide-eyed grownups everywhere.\nWhat's it about? Fencing. Fighting. True Love. Strong Hate. Harsh Revenge. A Few Giants. Lots of Bad Men. Lots of Good Men. Five or Six Beautiful Women. Beasties Monstrous and Gentle. Some Swell Escapes and Captures. Death

column14: Truth
column15: Miracles

column3: "title": "The Sweetness at the Bottom of the Pie (Flavia de Luce
column9: "description": "An enthralling mystery

column20: contradictions

column8: "description": "Gone with the Windis a novel written by Margaret Mitchell

column9: "description": "With her now-classic novel Outlander
column10: Diana Gabaldon introduced two unforgettable characters--Claire Randall and Jamie Fraser--delighting readers with a story of adventure and love that spanned two centuries. Now Gabaldon returns to that extraordinary time and place in this vivid

column9: an aging former punk rocker and record executive
column10: and Sasha
column11: the passionate

column18: San Francisco

column34: along with the lovers and children left behind in the wake of Lou's far-flung sexual conquests and meteoric rise and fall.\nA Visit from the Goon Squadis a book about the interplay of time and music
column36: about the stirrings and transformations set inexorably in motion by even the most passing conjunction of our fates. In a breathtaking array of styles and tones ranging from tragedy to satire to PowerPoint
column37: Egan captures the undertow of self-destruction that we all must either master or succumb to; the basic human hunger for redemption; and the universal tendency to reach for both--and escape the merciless progress of time--in the transporting realms of art and music. Sly
column39: exhilarating work from one of our boldest writers."}

column9: and would disapprove of most of all
column10: was that I watched the Garretts. All the time.\"\nThe Garretts are everything the Reeds are not. Loud
column11: messy
column12: affectionate. And every day from her rooftop perch
column13: Samantha Reed wishes she was one of them . . . until one summer evening
column14: Jase Garrett climbs up next to her and changes everything.\nAs the two fall fiercely for each other
column15: stumbling through the awkwardness and awesomeness of first love

column17: and the bottom drops out of Samantha's world. She's suddenly faced with an impossible decision. Which perfect family will save her? Or is it time she saved herself?\nA transporting debut about family
column18: friendship

column20: and how to be true to one person you love without betraying another."}

column9:
"description": "Mara Dyer believes life can't get any stranger than waking up in a hospital with no memory of how she got there.
It can.
She believes there must be more to the accident she can't remember that killed her friends and left her strangely unharmed.
There is.
She doesn't believe that after everything she's been through
column10: she can fall in love.\nShe's wrong."}

column9: "description": "I wasn't free of my past
column10: not yet.\nSydney's blood is special. That's because she's an alchemist - one of a group of humans who dabble in magic and serve to bridge the worlds of humans and vampires. They protect vampire secrets - and human lives. But the last encounter Sydney had with vampires got her in deep trouble with the other alchemists. And now with her allegiences in question
column11: her future is on the line.\nWhen Sydney is torn from her bed in the middle of the night
column12: at first she thinks she's still being punished for her complicated alliance with dhampir Rose Hathaway. But what unfolds is far worse. Jill Dragomir - the sister of Moroi Queen Lissa Dragomir - is in mortal danger
column13: and the Moroi must send her into hiding. To avoid a civil war
column14: Sydney is called upon to act as Jill's guardian and protector
column15: posing as her roommate in the unlikeliest of places: a human boarding school in Palm Springs
column16: California. The last thing Sydney wants is to be accused of sympathizing with vampires. And now she has to live with one.\nThe Moroi court believe Jill and Sydney will be safe at Amberwood Prep
column17: but threats
column18: distractions
column19: and forbidden romance lurk both outside - and within - the school grounds. Now that they're in hiding
column20: the drama is only just beginning."}

column3: "title": "Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis"
column8: "description": "From a former Marine and Yale Law School Graduate
column9: a poignant account of growing up in a poor Appalachian town
column10: that offers a broader
column11: probing look at the struggles of America's white working class. Part memoir
column12: part historical and social analysis
column13: J. D. Vance's Hillbilly Elegyis a fascinating consideration of class
column14: culture
column15: and the American dream.\nVance's grandparents were \"dirt poor and in love.\" They got married and moved north from Kentucky to Ohio in the hopes of escaping the dreadful poverty around them. Their grandchild (the author) graduated from Yale Law School
column16: a conventional marker of their success in achieving upward mobility for their family. But Vance cautions that is only the short version. The slightly longer version is that his grandparents
column17: aunt
column18: uncle
column19: and mother struggled to varying degrees with the demands of their new middle class life and they
column20: and Vance himself
column21: still carry around the demons of their chaotic family history.\nDelving into his own personal story and drawing on a wide array of sociological studies
column22: Vance takes us deep into working class life in the Appalachian region. This demographic of our country has been slowly disintegrating over forty years
column23: and Vance provides a searching and clear-eyed attempt to understand when and how \"hillbillies\" lost faith in any hope of upward mobility
column24: and in opportunities to come.\nAt times funny
column25: disturbing
column26: and deeply moving
column27: this is a family history that is also a troubling meditation on the loss of the American dream for a large portion of this country."}

column8: "description": "What does the legend of Vlad the Impaler have to do with the modern world? Is it possible that the Dracula of myth truly existed--and that he has lived on
column9: century after century
column10: pursuing his own unknowable ends? Elizabeth Kostova's debut novel is an adventure of monumental proportions
column11: a relentless tale that blends fact and fantasy
column12: history and the present
column13: with an assurance that is almost unbearably suspenseful--and utterly unforgettable.\n\"To you
column14: perceptive reader
column15: I bequeath my history....\"\nLate one night
column16: exploring her father's library
column17: a young woman finds an ancient book and a cache of yellowing letters. The letters are all addressed to \"My dear and unfortunate successor
column18: \" and they plunge her into a world she never dreamed of--a labyrinth where the secrets of her father's past and her mother's mysterious fate connect to an inconceivable evil hidden in the depths of history.\nThe letters provide links to one of the darkest powers that humanity has ever known--and to a centuries-long quest to find the source of that darkness and wipe it out. It is a quest for the truth about Vlad the Impaler
column19: the medieval ruler whose barbarous reign formed the basis of the legend of Dracula. Generations of historians have risked their reputations
column20: their sanity
column21: and even their lives to learn the truth about Vlad the Impaler and Dracula. Now one young woman must decide whether to take up this quest herself--to follow her father in a hunt that nearly brought him to ruin years ago
column22: when he was a vibrant young scholar and her mother was still alive.\nWhat does the legend of Vlad the Impaler have to do with the modern world? Is it possible that the Dracula of myth truly existed--and that he has lived on
column23: century after century
column24: pursuing his own unknowable ends? The answers to these questions cross time and borders
column25: as first the father and then the daughter search for clues
column26: from dusty Ivy League libraries to Istanbul
column27: Budapest
column28: and the depths of Eastern Europe. In city after city
column29: in monasteries and archives
column30: in letters and in secret conversations
column31: the horrible truth emerges about Vlad the Impaler's dark reign--and about a time-defying pact that may have kept his awful work alive down through the ages.\nParsing obscure signs and hidden texts
column32: reading codes worked into the fabric of medieval monastic traditions--and evading the unknown adversaries who will go to any lengths to conceal and protect Vlad's ancient powers--one woman comes ever closer to the secret of her own past and a confrontation with the very definition of evil. Elizabeth Kostova's debut novel is an adventure of monumental proportions
column33: a relentless tale that blends fact and fantasy
column35: with an assurance that is almost unbearably suspenseful--and utterly unforgettable."}

column10:
"description": "To want what you're not supposed to have...
She is only nineteen.
She is his new stepfather's daughter.
She is still naive and innocent due to spending the last three years taking care of her sick mother.
But for twenty-four year old Rush Finlay
column11: she is the only thing that has ever been off limits. His famous father's guilt money
column12: his mother's desperation to win his love
column13: and his charm are the three reasons he has never been told no.\nBlaire Wynn left her small farmhouse in Alabama
column14: after her mother passed away
column15: to move in with her father and his new wife in their sprawling beach house along the Florida gulf coast. She isn't prepared for the lifestyle change and she knows she'll never fit into this world. Then there is her sexy stepbrother who her father leaves her with for the summer while he runs off to Paris with his wife. Rush is as spoiled as he is gorgeous. He is also getting under her skin. She knows he is anything but good for her and that he'll never be faithful to anyone. He is jaded and has secrets Blaire knows she may never uncover but even knowing all of that...\nBlaire just may have fallen too far."}

column9: "description": "Now a New York TimesBestseller\nA hilarious
column10: thoughtful
column11: and in-depth exploration of the pleasures and perils of modern romance from one of this generation's sharpest comedic voices\nAt some point
column12: every one of us embarks on a journey to find love. We meet people
column13: date
column14: get into and out of relationships
column15: all with the hope of finding someone with whom we share a deep connection. This seems standard now
column16: but it's wildly different from what people did even just decades ago. Single people today have more romantic options than at any point in human history. With technology
column17: our abilities to connect with and sort through these options are staggering. So why are so many people frustrated?\nSome of our problems are unique to our time. \"Why did this guy just text me an emoji of a pizza?\" \"Should I go out with this girl even though she listed Combos as one of her favorite snack foods? Combos?!\" \"My girlfriend just got a message from some dude named Nathan. Who's Nathan? Did he just send her a photo of his penis? Should I check just to be sure?\"\nBut the transformation of our romantic lives can't be explained by technology alone. In a short period of time
column18: the whole culture of finding love has changed dramatically. A few decades ago
column19: people would find a decent person who lived in their neighborhood. Their families would meet and
column20: after deciding neither party seemed like a murderer
column21: they would get married and soon have a kid
column22: all by the time they were twenty-four. Today
column23: people marry later than ever and spend years of their lives on a quest to find the perfect person
column24: a soul mate.\nFor years
column25: Aziz Ansari has been aiming his comic insight at modern romance
column26: but for Modern Romance
column27: the book
column28: he decided he needed to take things to another level. He teamed up with NYU sociologist Eric Klinenberg and designed a massive research project
column29: including hundreds of interviews and focus groups conducted everywhere from Tokyo to Buenos Aires to Wichita. They analyzed behavioral data and surveys and created their own online research forum on Reddit
column30: which drew thousands of messages. They enlisted the world's leading social scientists
column31: including Andrew Cherlin
column32: Eli Finkel
column37: and Robb Willer. The result is unlike any social science or humor book we've seen before.\nIn Modern Romance
column38: Ansari combines his irreverent humor with cutting-edge social science to give us an unforgettable tour of our new romantic world."}

column8: "description": "I've lost it. :( The only thing in the world I wasn't supposed to lose. My engagement ring. It's been in Magnus's family for three generations. And now the very same day his parents are coming

column10: Poppy. Stay positive :) !!\nPoppy Wyatt has never felt luckier. She is about to marry her ideal man

column15: perfect except that the phone's owner
column16: businessman Sam Roxton
column17: doesn't agree. He wants his phone back and doesn't appreciate Poppy reading his messages and wading into his personal life.\nWhat ensues is a hilarious and unpredictable turn of events as Poppy and Sam increasingly upend each other's lives through emails and text messages. As Poppy juggles wedding preparations
column18: mysterious phone calls
column19: and hiding her left hand from Magnus and his parents . . . she soon realizes that she is in for the biggest surprise of her life."}

column9: funny
column10: triumphant novel that exalts the quiet victories of the inconspicuous among us.\nWe are in the center of Paris

column12: the concierge

column14: cantankerous
column15: addicted to television. Yet
column16: unbeknownst to her employers
column17: Renee is a cultured autodidact who adores art
column18: philosophy
column19: music

column21: who for their part are barely aware of her existence.\nThen there's Paloma
column22: a twelve-year-old genius. She is the daughter of a tedious parliamentarian
column23: a talented and startlingly lucid child who has decided to end her life on the sixteenth of June
column24: her thirteenth birthday. Until then she will continue behaving as everyone expects her to behave: a mediocre pre-teen high on adolescent subculture
column25: a good but not an outstanding student
column26: an obedient if obstinate daughter.\nPaloma and Renee hide both their true talents and their finest qualities from a world they suspect cannot or will not appreciate them. They discover their kindred souls when a wealthy Japanese man named Ozu arrives in the building. Only he is able to gain Paloma's trust and to see through Renee's timeworn disguise to the secret that haunts her. This is a moving
column27: funny
column28: triumphant novel that exalts the quiet victories of the inconspicuous among us."}

column8: "description": "Librarian's Note: An alternate cover edition can be found \u0001\nIn April 1992 a young man from a well-to-do family hitchhiked to Alaska and walked alone into the wilderness north of Mt. McKinley. His name was Christopher Johnson McCandless. He had given $25
column9: 000 in savings to charity
column10: abandoned his car and most of his possessions
column11: burned all the cash in his wallet
column12: and invented a new life for himself. Four months later
column13: a party of moose hunters found his decomposed body. How McCandless came to die is the unforgettable story of Into the Wild.\nImmediately after graduating from college in 1991
column14: McCandless had roamed through the West and Southwest on a vision quest like those made by his heroes Jack London and John Muir. In the Mojave Desert he abandoned his car
column15: stripped it of its license plates
column16: and burned all of his cash. He would give himself a new name
column17: Alexander Supertramp
column18: and
column19: unencumbered by money and belongings
column20: he would be free to wallow in the raw
column21: unfiltered experiences that nature presented. Craving a blank spot on the map
column22: McCandless simply threw away the maps. Leaving behind his desperate parents and sister
column23: he vanished into the wild."}

column10: and each other

column13: Ky outside the borders

column9: "description": "See the world of Fifty Shades of Greyanew through the eyes of Christian Grey.\nIn Christian's own words
column10: and through his thoughts
column11: reflections

column14: disciplined
column15: and utterly empty--until the day that Anastasia Steele falls into his office
column16: in a tangle of shapely limbs and tumbling brown hair. He tries to forget her

column18: shy
column19: unworldly Ana seems to see right through him--past the business prodigy and the penthouse lifestyle to Christian's cold

column8: "description": "The Poisonwood Bible is a story told by the wife and four daughters of Nathan Price
column9: a fierce
column10: evangelical Baptist who takes his family and mission to the Belgian Congo in 1959. They carry with them everything they believe they will need from home
column11: but soon find that all of it -- from garden seeds to Scripture -- is calamitously transformed on African soil. What follows is a suspenseful epic of one family's tragic undoing and remarkable reconstruction over the course of three decades in postcolonial Africa."}

column9: "description": "\"I won't tell anyone
column10: Echo. I promise.\" Noah tucked a curl behind my ear. It had been so long since someone touched me like he did. Why did it have to be Noah Hutchins? His dark brown eyes shifted to my covered arms. \"You didn't do that-did you? It was done to you?\" No one ever asked that question. They stared. They whispered. They laughed. But they never asked.\nSo wrong for each other...and yet so right.\nNo one knows what happened the night Echo Emerson went from popular girl with jock boyfriend to gossiped-about outsider with \"freaky\" scars on her arms. Even Echo can't remember the whole truth of that horrible night. All she knows is that she wants everything to go back to normal. But when Noah Hutchins
column11: the smoking-hot
column12: girl-using loner in the black leather jacket
column13: explodes into her life with his tough attitude and surprising understanding
column14: Echo's world shifts in ways she could never have imagined. They should have nothing in common. And with the secrets they both keep
column15: being together is pretty muchimpossible. Yet the crazy attraction between them refuses to go away. And Echo has to ask herself just how far they can push the limits and what she'll risk for the one guy who might teach her how to love again..."}

column9:
"description": "A princess must find her place in a reborn world.

She is pursued by bounty hunters sent by her own father.
She is Princess Lia
column10: seventeen
column11: First Daughter of the House of Morrighan.\nThe Kingdom of Morrighan is steeped in tradition and the stories of a bygone world
column12: but some traditions Lia can't abide. Like having to marry someone she's never met to secure a political alliance.\nFed up and ready for a new life
column13: Lia flees to a distant village on the morning of her wedding. She settles in among the common folk
column14: intrigued when two mysterious and handsome strangers arrive--and unaware that one is the jilted prince and the other an assassin sent to kill her. Deceptions swirl and Lia finds herself on the brink of unlocking perilous secrets--secrets that may unravel her world--even as she feels herself falling in love."}

column12: for her cousin Vinnie's company. She questions \"working girls\" to find the missing girlfriend of vicious prizefighter Benito Ramirez while Joe secretly watches her back. Ranger mentors her and supplies vehicles when hers explode."}

column9: written as a letter to his son
column10: Coates confronts the notion of race in America and how it has shaped American history
column11: many times at the cost of black bodies and lives. Thoughtfully exploring personal and historical events
column12: from his time at Howard University to the Civil War
column13: the author poignantly asks and attempts to answer difficult questions that plague modern society. In this short memoir
column14: the \"Atlantic\" writer explains that the tragic examples of Michael Brown
column15: Trayvon Martin
column16: and those killed in South Carolina are the results of a systematically constructed and maintained assault to black people--a structure that includes slavery
column17: mass incarceration
column18: and police brutality as part of its foundation. From his passionate and deliberate breakdown of the concept of race itself to the importance of the Black Lives Matter movement
column19: Coates powerfully sums up the terrible history of the subjugation of black people in the United States. A timely work
column20: this title will resonate with all teens--those who have experienced racism as well as those who have followed the recent news coverage on violence against people of color."}

column8: "description": "Tana lives in a world where walled cities called Coldtowns exist. In them
column9: quarantined monsters and humans mingle in a decadently bloody mix of predator and prey. The only problem is
column10: once you pass through Coldtown's gates
column11: you can never leave.\nOne morning
column12: after a perfectly ordinary party
column13: Tana wakes up surrounded by corpses. The only other survivors of this massacre are her exasperatingly endearing ex-boyfriend
column14: infected and on the edge
column15: and a mysterious boy burdened with a terrible secret. Shaken and determined
column16: Tana enters a race against the clock to save the three of them the only way she knows how: by going straight to the wicked
column17: opulent heart of Coldtown itself.\nThe Coldest Girl in Coldtownis a wholly original story of rage and revenge
column18: of guilt and horror
column19: and of love and loathing from bestselling and acclaimed author Holly Black."}

column9: "description": "Here lives an orphaned ward named Lyra Belacqua
column10: whose carefree life among the scholars at Oxford's Jordan College is shattered by the arrival of two powerful visitors. First
column11: her fearsome uncle
column12: Lord Asriel
column13: appears with evidence of mystery and danger in the far North
column14: including photographs of a mysterious celestial phenomenon called Dust and the dim outline of a city suspended in the Aurora Borealis that he suspects is part of an alternate universe. He leaves Lyra in the care of Mrs. Coulter
column15: an enigmatic scholar and explorer who offers to give Lyra the attention her uncle has long refused her. In this multilayered narrative
column16: however
column17: nothingis as it seems. Lyra sets out for the top of the world in search of her kidnapped playmate
column18: Roger
column19: bearing a rare truth-telling instrument
column20: the alethiometer. All around her children are disappearing--victims of so-called \"Gobblers\"--and being used as subjects in terrible experiments that separate humans from their daemons
column21: creatures that reflect each person's inner being. And somehow
column22: both Lord Asriel and Mrs. Coulter are involved."}

column9: "description": "She's about to make a deal with the college bad boy...\nHannah Wells has finally found someone who turns her on. But while she might be confident in every other area of her life
column10: she's carting around a full set of baggage when it comes to sex and seduction. If she wants to get her crush's attention
column11: she'll have to step out of her comfort zone and makehim take notice...even if it means tutoring the annoying
column12: childish
column13: cockycaptain of the hockey team in exchange for a pretend date.\n...and it's going to be oh so good\nAll Garrett Graham has ever wanted is to play professional hockey after graduation
column14: but his plummeting GPA is threatening everything he's worked so hard for. If helping a sarcastic brunette make another guy jealous will help him secure his position on the team
