column16: it doesn't take long for Garrett to realize that pretend isn't going to cut it. Now he just has to convince Hannah that the man she wants looks a lot like him."}

column9: a boyfriend
column10: and a loving family
column11: Piper Kerman barely resembles the reckless young woman who delivered a suitcase of drug money ten years before.\nBut that past has caught up with her.\nConvicted and sentenced to fifteen months at the infamous federal correctional facility in Danbury
column12: Connecticut
column13: the well-heeled Smith College alumna is now inmate #11187-424 -- one of the millions of people who disappear \"down the rabbit hole\" of the American penal system.\nFrom her first strip search to her final release
column14: Kerman learns to navigate this strange world with its strictly enforced codes of behavior and arbitrary rules. She meets women from all walks of life
column15: who surprise her with small tokens of generosity
column16: hard words of wisdom
column17: and simple acts of acceptance.\nHeartbreaking
column18: hilarious
column19: and at times enraging
column20: Kerman's story offers a rare look into the lives of women in prison--why it is we lock so many away and what happens to them when they're there."}

column9: "description": "A fresh
column10: urban twist on the classic tale of star-crossed lovers.\nWhen Brittany Ellis walks into chemistry class on the first day of senior year
column11: she has no clue that her carefully created 'perfect' life is about to unravel before her eyes. She's forced to be lab partners with Alex Fuentes
column12: a gang member from the other side of town
column13: and he is about to threaten everything she's worked so hard for: her flawless reputation
column14: her relationship with her boyfriend
column15: and the secret that her home life is anything but perfect.\nAlex is a bad boy and he knows it. So when he makes a bet with his friends to lure Brittany into his life
column16: he thinks nothing of it. But soon Alex realizes Brittany is a real person with real problems
column17: and suddenly the bet he made in arrogance turns into something much more.\nIn a passionate story about looking beneath the surface
column18: Simone Elkeles breaks through the stereotypes and barriers that threaten to keep Brittany and Alex apart."}

column8: "description": "An internationally bestselling phenomenon: the darkly suspenseful
column9: highly controversial tale of two families struggling to make the hardest decision of their lives - all over the course of one meal.\nIt's a summer's evening in Amsterdam
column10: and two couples meet at a fashionable restaurant for dinner. Between mouthfuls of food and over the polite scrapings of cutlery
column11: the conversation remains a gentle hum of polite discourse - the banality of work
column12: the triviality of the holidays. But behind the empty words
column13: terrible things need to be said
column14: and with every forced smile and every new course
column15: the knives are being sharpened.\nEach couple has a fifteen-year-old son. The two boys are united by their accountability for a single horrific act; an act that has triggered a police investigation and shattered the comfortable
column16: insulated worlds of their families. As the dinner reaches its culinary climax
column17: the conversation finally touches on their children. As civility and friendship disintegrate
column18: each couple show just how far they are prepared to go to protect those they love.\nTautly written
column19: incredibly gripping
column20: and told by an unforgettable narrator
column21: The Dinner promises to be the topic of countless dinner party debates. Skewering everything from parenting values to pretentious menus to political convictions
column22: this novel reveals the dark side of genteel society and asks what each of us would do in the face of unimaginable tragedy."}

column9: "description": "When a beautiful
column10: aspiring writer strides into the East Village bookstore where Joe Goldberg works

column12: telling Joe everything he needs to know: she is simply Beck to her friends
column13: she went to Brown University
column14: she lives on Bank Street
column15: and she'll be at a bar in Brooklyn tonight--the perfect place for a \"chance\" meeting.\nAs Joe invisibly and obsessively takes control of Beck's life
column16: he orchestrates a series of events to ensure Beck finds herself in his waiting arms. Moving from stalker to boyfriend
column17: Joe transforms himself into Beck's perfect man
column18: all while quietly removing the obstacles that stand in their way--even if it means murder."}

column9: "description": "Evie O'Neill has been exiled from her boring old hometown and shipped off to the bustling streets of New York City--and she is pos-i-tute-ly ecstatic. It's 1926
column10: and New York is filled with speakeasies
column11: Ziegfeld girls

The only catch is that she has to live with her uncle Will and his unhealthy obsession with the occult.\nEvie worries he'll discover her darkest secret: a supernatural power that has only brought her trouble so far. But when the police find a murdered girl branded with a cryptic symbol and Will is called to the scene
column13: Evie realizes her gift could help catch a serial killer.\nAs Evie jumps headlong into a dance with a murderer
column14: other stories unfold in the city that never sleeps. A young man named Memphis is caught between two worlds. A chorus girl named Theta is running from her past. A student named Jericho hides a shocking secret. And unknown to all
column15: something dark and evil has awakened."}

column9: crazy about her husband
column10: and pregnant with her first child.\nSo imagine Alice's surprise when she comes to on the floor of a gym and is whisked off to the hospital where she discovers the honeymoon is truly over -- she's getting divorced
column11: she has three kids and she's actually 39 years old. Alice must reconstruct the events of a lost decade

column13: and how is it that she's become one of those super skinny moms with really expensive clothes.\nUltimately

column15: and whether it's possible to start over."}

column8: "description": "An unforgettable journey into one man's remarkable life
column9: and an epic story about the power
column10: intimacy
column11: and curious beauty of the work of healing others set in 1960s & 1970s Ethiopia and 1980s America.\nMarion and Shiva Stone are twin brothers born of a secret union between a beautiful Indian nun and a brash British surgeon at a mission hospital in Addis Ababa. Orphaned by their mother's death in childbirth and their father's disappearance
column12: bound together by a preternatural connection and a shared fascination with medicine
column13: the twins come of age as Ethiopia hovers on the brink of revolution. Yet it will be love
column14: not politics--their passion for the same woman--that will tear them apart and force Marion
column15: fresh out of medical school
column16: to flee his homeland. He makes his way to America

And that would be ridiculous because no one would invite a herdof kangaroos into their house.Two is the limit. I speak from personal experience. My husband says that noneis the new limit. I say he should have been clearer about that before I rented all those kangaroos.\"\n\"Most of my favorite people are dangerously fucked-up but you'd never guess because we've learned to bare it so honestly that it becomes the new normal. column9: "description": "Gideon Cross. As beautiful and flawless on the outside as he was damaged and tormented on the inside. He was a bright

column8: "description": "A beautiful clothbound edition of the internationally acclaimed Fahrenheit 451 - a masterwork of twentieth-century literature.\nThe terrifyingly prophetic novel of a post-literate future.\nGuy Montag is a fireman. His job is to burn books

column13: escorted by helicopters
column14: is ready to track down those dissidents who defy society to preserve and read books.\nThe classic dystopian novel of a post-literate future
column15: Fahrenheit 451 stands alongside Orwell's 1984 and Huxley's Brave New World as a prophetic account of Western civilization's enslavement by the media
column16: drugs and conformity.\nBradbury's powerful and poetic prose combines with uncanny insight into the potential of technology to create a novel which
column17: decades on from first publication

column9: Kafka Tamura

column9: Carol Rifka Brunt unfolds a moving story of love

column9: Shakespeare creates a world of violence and generational conflict in which two young people fall in love and die because of that love. The story is rather extraordinary in that the normal problems faced by young lovers are here so very large. It is not simply that the families of Romeo and Juliet disapprove of the lover's affection for each other; rather
column10: the Montagues and the Capulets are on opposite sides in a blood feud and are trying to kill each other on the streets of Verona. Every time a member of one of the two families dies in the fight
column11: his relatives demand the blood of his killer. Because of the feud
column12: if Romeo is discovered with Juliet by her family
column13: he will be killed. Once Romeo is banished
column14: the only way that Juliet can avoid being married to someone else is to take a potion that apparently kills her
column15: so that she is burried with the bodies of her slain relatives. In this violent
column16: death-filled world
column17: the movement of the story from love at first sight to the union of the lovers in death seems almost inevitable.\nWhat is so striking about this play is that despite its extraordinary setting (one perhaps reflecting Elizabethan attitudes about hot-blooded Italians)
column18: it has become the quintessential story of young love. Because most young lovers feel that they have to overcome giant obstacles in order to be together
column19: because they feel that they would rather die than be kept apart
column20: and especially because the language Shakespeare gives his young lovers is so exquisite
column21: allowing them to say to each other just what we would all say to a lover if we only knew how
column22: it is easy to respond to this play as if it were about all young lovers rather than about a particular couple in a very unusual world. (When the play was rewritten in the eighteen century as The History and Fall of Caius Marius
column23: the violent setting became that of a particularly discordant period in classical Rome; when Leonard Berstein rewrote the play as West Side Story
column24: he chose the violent world of New York street gangs.)"}

column9: "description": "Winner of the 2015 Nebula Award.\nArea X has been cut off from the rest of the continent for decades. Nature has reclaimed the last vestiges of human civilization. The first expedition returned with reports of a pristine

column17: above all

column3: "title": "The Hundred-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out of the Window and Disappeared"

column13: several murders
column14: a suitcase full of cash
column15: and incompetent police. As his escapades unfold

column18: Russian tyrants
column19: and Chinese leaders
column20: and was a participant behind the scenes in many key events of the twentieth century. Already a huge bestseller across Europe

column10:
n.
i. A brief section of music composed of a series of notes and flourishes.

column16: Nicholas' passenger

"description": "A fallen boxer.

column13: within moments

column16: he can slip right out of the everyday world

column18: one day

column20: the only kid to ever escape Manx's unmitigated evil
column21: is all grown up and desperate to forget. But Charlie Manx never stopped thinking about Victoria McQueen. He's on the road again and he's picked up a new passenger: Vic's own son."}

column9: funny and acutely perceptive debut novel about four adult siblings and the fate of the shared inheritance that has shaped their choices and their lives.\nEvery family has its problems. But even among the most troubled

column11: Beatrice

column21: an antiques dealer

column23: Walker

column27: by extension

column29: Leo
column30: Melody
column31: Jack
column32: and Beatrice must grapple with old resentments
column34: and the significant emotional and financial toll of the accident
column35: as well as finally acknowledge the choices they have made in their own lives.\nThis is a story about the power of family
column37: the ways we depend upon one another and the ways we let one another down. In this tender
column40: Sweeney brings a remarkable cast of characters to life to illuminate what money does to relationships

and even unforeseen love.

column8: "description": "Sage Singer befriends an old man who's particularly beloved in her community. Josef Weber is everyone's favorite retired teacher and Little League coach. They strike up a friendship at the bakery where Sage works. One day he asks Sage for a favor: to kill him. Shocked
column9: Sage refuses... and then he confesses his darkest secret--he deserves to die

Can someone who's committed a truly heinous act ever atone for it with subsequent good behavior? Should you offer forgiveness to someone if you aren't the party who was wronged? And most of all--if Sage even considers his request--is it murder

column8: "description": "Subtitle: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail. The Appalachian Trail stretches from Georgia to Maine and covers some of the most breathtaking terrain in America-majestic mountains
column9: silent forests

column11: it's probably the place to go. And Bill Bryson is surely the most entertaining guide you'll find. He introduces us to the history and ecology of the trail and to some of the other hardy (or just foolhardy) folks he meets along the way-and a couple of bears. Already a classic

column12: and to learn their dance numbers in case they are rescued in time for the competition."}

column8: "description": "Twenty-seven-year old Anne Elliot is Austen's most adult heroine. Eight years before the story proper begins

column10: Frederick Wentworth
column11: but she precipitously breaks off the engagement when persuaded by her friend Lady Russell that such a match is unworthy. The breakup produces in Anne a deep and long-lasting regret. When later Wentworth returns from sea a rich and successful captain
column12: he finds Anne's family on the brink of financial ruin and his own sister a tenant in Kellynch Hall
column13: the Elliot estate. All the tension of the novel revolves around one question: Will Anne and Wentworth be reunited in their love?\nJane Austen once compared her writing to painting on a little bit of ivory
column14: 2 inches square. Readers of Persuasionwill discover that neither her skill for delicate
column15: ironic observations on social custom
column16: love
column17: and marriage nor her ability to apply a sharp focus lens to English manners and morals has deserted her in her final finished work."}

column11: her brother has traveled the world with their father
column12: the brilliant Egyptologist

column9: "description": "The long-awaited second book in the dystopian Matchedtrilogy.\nIn search of a future that may not exist and faced with the decision of who to share it with
column10: Cassia journeys to the Outer Provinces in pursuit of Ky - taken by the Society to his certain death - only to find that he has escaped
column11: leaving a series of clues in his wake. Cassia's quest leads her to question much of what she holds dear
column12: even as she finds glimmers of a different life across the border. But as Cassia nears resolve and certainty about her future with Ky
column13: an invitation for rebellion
column14: an unexpected betrayal
column15: and a surprise visit from Xander - who may hold the key to the uprising and
column16: still
column17: to Cassia's heart - change the game once again. Nothing is as expected on the edge of Society
column18: where crosses and double crosses make the path more twisted than ever."}

column9: "description": "As a Red
column10: Darrow grew up working the mines deep beneath the surface of Mars
column11: enduring backbreaking labor while dreaming of the better future he was building for his descendants. But the Society he faithfully served was built on lies. Darrow's kind have been betrayed and denied by their elitist masters
column12: the Golds--and their only path to liberation is revolution. And so Darrow sacrifices himself in the name of the greater good for which Eo
column13: his true love and inspiration
column14: laid down her own life. He becomes a Gold
column15: infiltrating their privileged realm so that he can destroy it from within.\nA lamb among wolves in a cruel world
column16: Darrow finds friendship
column17: respect
column18: and even love--but also the wrath of powerful rivals. To wage and win the war that will change humankind's destiny
column19: Darrow must confront the treachery arrayed against him
column20: overcome his all-too-human desire for retribution--and strive not for violent revolt but a hopeful rebirth. Though the road ahead is fraught with danger and deceit
column21: Darrow must choose to follow Eo's principles of love and justice to free his people.\nHe must live for more."}

column8: "description": "When a white servant girl violates the order of plantation society
column9: she unleashes a tragedy that exposes the worst and best in the people she has come to call her family. Orphaned while onboard ship from Ireland
column10: seven-year-old Lavinia arrives on the steps of a tobacco plantation where she is to live and work with the slaves of the kitchen house. Under the care of Belle
column11: the master's illegitimate daughter
column12: Lavinia becomes deeply bonded to her adopted family
column13: though she is set apart from them by her white skin.\nEventually
column14: Lavinia is accepted into the world of the big house
column15: where the master is absent and the mistress battles opium addiction. Lavinia finds herself perilously straddling two very different worlds. When she is forced to make a choice
column16: loyalties are brought into question
column17: dangerous truths are laid bare
column18: and lives are put at risk."}

column9: "description": "Gwyneth Shepherd's sophisticated
column10: beautiful cousin Charlotte has been prepared her entire life for traveling through time. But unexpectedly
column11: it is Gwyneth
column12: who in the middle of class takes a sudden spin to a different era!\nGwyneth must now unearth the mystery of why her mother would lie about her birth date to ward off suspicion about her ability
column13: brush up on her history
column14: and work with Gideon--the time traveler from a similarly gifted family that passes the gene through its male line
column15: and whose presence becomes
column16: in time
column17: less insufferable and more essential. Together
column18: Gwyneth and Gideon journey through time to discover who
column19: in the 18th century and in contemporary London
column20: they can trust."}

column9: witty
column10: and ingeniously convincing
column11: Susanna Clarke's magisterial novel weaves magic into a flawlessly detailed vision of historical England. She has created a world so thoroughly enchanting that eight hundred pages leave readers longing for more.\nEnglish magicians were once the wonder of the known world
column12: with fairy servants at their beck and call; they could command winds
column13: mountains
column14: and woods. But by the early 1800s they have long since lost the ability to perform magic. They can only write long
column15: dull papers about it
column16: while fairy servants are nothing but a fading memory.\nBut at Hurtfew Abbey in Yorkshire
column17: the rich
column18: reclusive Mr Norrell has assembled a wonderful library of lost and forgotten books from England's magical past and regained some of the powers of England's magicians. He goes to London and raises a beautiful young woman from the dead. Soon he is lending his help to the government in the war against Napoleon Bonaparte
column19: creating ghostly fleets of rain-ships to confuse and alarm the French.\nAll goes well until a rival magician appears. Jonathan Strange is handsome
column20: charming
column21: and talkative-the very opposite of Mr Norrell. Strange thinks nothing of enduring the rigors of campaigning with Wellington's army and doing magic on battlefields. Astonished to find another practicing magician
column22: Mr Norrell accepts Strange as a pupil. But it soon becomes clear that their ideas of what English magic ought to be are very different. For Mr Norrell
column23: their power is something to be cautiously controlled
column24: while Jonathan Strange will always be attracted to the wildest
column25: most perilous forms of magic. He becomes fascinated by the ancient
column26: shadowy figure of the Raven King
column27: a child taken by fairies who became king of both England and Faerie
column28: and the most legendary magician of all. Eventually Strange's heedless pursuit of long-forgotten magic threatens to destroy not only his partnership with Norrell
column29: but everything that he holds dear."}

column10: "description": "Victor and Eli started out as college roommates--brilliant
column11: arrogant
column12: lonely boys who recognized the same sharpness and ambition in each other. In their senior year
column13: a shared research interest in adrenaline
column14: near-death experiences
column15: and seemingly supernatural events reveals an intriguing possibility: that under the right conditions
column16: someone could develop extraordinary abilities. But when their thesis moves from the academic to the experimental
column17: things go horribly wrong.\nTen years later
column18: Victor breaks out of prison
column19: determined to catch up to his old friend (now foe)
column20: aided by a young girl whose reserved nature obscures a stunning ability. Meanwhile
column21: Eli is on a mission to eradicate every other super-powered person that he can find--aside from his sidekick
column22: an enigmatic woman with an unbreakable will. Armed with terrible power on both sides
column23: driven by the memory of betrayal and loss
column24: the archnemeses have set a course for revenge--but who will be left alive at the end?"}

column8: "description": "What does \"feminism\" mean today? That is the question at the heart of We Should All Be Feminists
column9: a personal
column10: eloquently-argued essay--adapted from her much-viewed TEDx talk of the same name--by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
column11: the award-winning author of Americanahand Half of a Yellow Sun.\nWith humor and levity
column12: here Adichie offers readers a unique definition of feminism for the twenty-first century--one rooted in inclusion and awareness. She shines a light not only on blatant discrimination
column13: but also the more insidious
column14: institutional behaviors that marginalize women around the world
column15: in order to help readers of all walks of life better understand the often masked realities of sexual politics. Throughout
column16: she draws extensively on her own experiences--in the U.S.
column17: in her native Nigeria
column18: and abroad--offering an artfully nuanced explanation of why the gender divide is harmful for women and men
column19: alike.\nArgued in the same observant
column20: witty and clever prose that has made Adichie a bestselling novelist
column21: here is one remarkable author's exploration of what it means to be a woman today--and an of-the-moment rallying cry for why we should all be feminists."}

column8: "description": "HER PERFECT LIFE IS A PERFECT LIE.\nAs a teenager at the prestigious Bradley School
column9: Ani FaNelli endured a shocking
column10: public humiliation that left her desperate to reinvent herself. Now
column11: with a glamorous job
column12: expensive wardrobe
column13: and handsome blue blood fiance
column14: she's this close to living the perfect life she's worked so hard to achieve.\nBut Ani has a secret.\nThere's something else buried in her past that still haunts her
column15: something private and painful that threatens to bubble to the surface and destroy everything.\nWith a singular voice and twists you won't see coming
column16: Luckiest Girl Alive explores the unbearable pressure that so many women feel to \"have it all\" and introduces a heroine whose sharp edges and cutthroat ambition have been protecting a scandalous truth
column17: and a heart that's bigger than it first appears.\nThe question remains: will breaking her silence destroy all that she has worked for--or
column18: will it at long last
column19: set Ani free?"}

column9: Andrew Solomon
column10: and Anne Lamott
column11: a profoundly moving
column12: exquisitely observed memoir by a young neurosurgeon faced with a terminal cancer diagnosis who attempts to answer the question What makes a life worth living?\nAt the age of thirty-six
column13: on the verge of completing a decade's worth of training as a neurosurgeon
column14: Paul Kalanithi was diagnosed with stage IV lung cancer. One day he was a doctor treating the dying
column15: and the next he was a patient struggling to live. And just like that
column16: the future he and his wife had imagined evaporated. When Breath Becomes Air chronicles Kalanithi's transformation from a naive medical student \"possessed
column17: \" as he wrote
column18: \"by the question of what
column19: given that all organisms die
column20: makes a virtuous and meaningful life\" into a neurosurgeon at Stanford working in the brain
column21: the most critical place for human identity
column22: and finally into a patient and new father confronting his own mortality.\nWhat makes life worth living in the face of death? What do you do when the future
column23: no longer a ladder toward your goals in life
column24: flattens out into a perpetual present? What does it mean to have a child
column25: to nurture a new life as another fades away? These are some of the questions Kalanithi wrestles with in this profoundly moving
column26: exquisitely observed memoir.\nPaul Kalanithi died in March 2015
column27: while working on this book
column28: yet his words live on as a guide and a gift to us all. \"I began to realize that coming face to face with my own mortality
column29: in a sense
column30: had changed nothing and everything
column31: \" he wrote. \"Seven words from Samuel Beckett began to repeat in my head: 'I can't go on. I'll go on.'\" When Breath Becomes Air is an unforgettable
column32: life-affirming reflection on the challenge of facing death and on the relationship between doctor and patient
column33: from a brilliant writer who became both."}

column9: equality
column10: fraternity
column11: or death; -- the last
column12: much the easiest to bestow
column13: O Guillotine!'\nAfter eighteen years as a political prisoner in the Bastille
column14: the ageing Doctor Manette is finally released and reunited with his daughter in England. There the lives of two very different men
column15: Charles Darnay
column16: an exiled French aristocrat
column17: and Sydney Carton
column18: a disreputable but brilliant English lawyer
column19: become enmeshed through their love for Lucie Manette. From the tranquil roads of London
column20: they are drawn against their will to the vengeful
column21: bloodstained streets of Paris at the height of the Reign of Terror
column22: and they soon fall under the lethal shadow of La Guillotine.\nThis edition uses the text as it appeared in its serial publication in 1859 to convey the full scope of Dickens's vision
column23: and includes the original illustrations by H. K. Browne ('Phiz'). Richard Maxwell's introduction discusses the intricate interweaving of epic drama with personal tragedy.\n--back cover"}

column9: "description": "Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Childrenwas the surprise best seller of 2011--an unprecedented mix of YA fantasy and vintage photography that enthralled readers and critics alike. Publishers Weekly called it \"an enjoyable
column10: eccentric read
column11: distinguished by well-developed characters
column12: a believable Welsh setting
column13: and some very creepy monsters.\"\nThis second novel begins in 1940
column14: immediately after the first book ended. Having escaped Miss Peregrine's island by the skin of their teeth
column15: Jacob and his new friends must journey to London
column16: the peculiar capital of the world. Along the way
column17: they encounter new allies
column18: a menagerie of peculiar animals
column19: and other unexpected surprises.\nComplete with dozens of newly discovered (and thoroughly mesmerizing) vintage photographs
column20: this new adventure will delight readers of all ages."}

column8: "description": "\"It still amazes me how little we really knew. . . . Maybe everything that happened to me and my family had nothing at all to do with the slowing. It's possible
column9: I guess. But I doubt it. I doubt it very much.\"\nLuminous
column10: haunting
column11: unforgettable
column12: The Age of Miraclesis a stunning fiction debut by a superb new writer
column13: a story about coming of age during extraordinary times
column14: about people going on with their lives in an era of profound uncertainty.\nOn a seemingly ordinary Saturday in a California suburb
column15: 11-year-old Julia and her family awake to discover
column16: along with the rest of the world
column17: that the rotation of the earth has suddenly begun to slow. The days and nights grow longer and longer
column18: gravity is affected
column19: the environment is thrown into disarray. Yet as she struggles to navigate an ever-shifting landscape
column20: Julia is also coping with the normal disasters of everyday life--the fissures in her parents' marriage
column21: the loss of old friends
column22: the hopeful anguish of first love
column23: the bizarre behavior of her grandfather who
column24: convinced of a government conspiracy
column25: spends his days obsessively cataloging his possessions. As Julia adjusts to the new normal
column26: the slowing inexorably continues.\nWith spare
column27: graceful prose and the emotional wisdom of a born storyteller
column28: Karen Thompson Walker has created a singular narrator in Julia
column29: a resilient and insightful young girl
column30: and a moving portrait of family life set against the backdrop of an utterly altered world."}

column9: "description": "Flirting with the Grave...Half-vampire Catherine Crawfield is going after the undead with a vengeance
column10: hoping that one of these deadbeats is her father - the one responsible for ruining her mother's life. Then she's captured by Bones
column11: a vampire bounty hunter
column12: and is forced into an unholy partnership.\nIn exchange for finding her father
column13: Cat agrees to train with the sexy night stalker until her battle reflexes are as sharp as his fangs. She's amazed she doesn't end up as his dinner - are there actually goodvampires? Pretty soon Bones will have her convinced that being half-dead doesn't have to be all bad. But before she can enjoy her newfound status as kick-ass demon hunter
column14: Cat and Bones are pursued by a group of killers. Now Cat will have to choose a side . . . and Bones is turning out to be as tempting as any man with a heartbeat."}

column9: "description": "Ten years ago
column10: Calamity came. It was a burst in the sky that gave ordinary men and women extraordinary powers. The awed public started calling them Epics. But Epics are no friend of man. With incredible gifts came the desire to rule. And to rule man you must crush his will.\nNobody fights the Epics...nobody but the Reckoners. A shadowy group of ordinary humans
column11: they spend their lives studying Epics
column12: finding their weaknesses
column13: and then assassinating them.\nAnd David wants in. He wants Steelheart -- the Epic who is said to be invincible. The Epic who killed David's father. For years
column14: like the Reckoners
column15: David's been studying
column16: and planning -- and he has something they need. Not an object
column17: but an experience.\nHe's seen Steelheart bleed. And he wants revenge."}

column9: when the wind blows from the sea and mingles with the scent of lilacs
column10: Landon Carter remembers his last year at Beaufort High. It was 1958
column11: and Landon had already dated a girl or two. He even swore that he had once been in love. Certainly the last person in town he thought he'd fall for was Jamie Sullivan
column12: the daughter of the town's Baptist minister.\nA quiet girl who always carried a Bible with her schoolbooks
column13: Jamie seemed content living in a world apart from the other teens. She took care of her widowed father
column14: rescued hurt animals
column15: and helped out at the local orphanage. No boy had ever asked her out. Landon would never have dreamed of it.\nThen a twist of fate made Jamie his partner for the homecoming dance
column16: and Landon Carter's life would never be the same. Being with Jamie would show him the depths of the human heart and lead him to a decision so stunning it would send him irrevocably on the road to manhood...\nDid You Know?-\nThat Jamie was named after Nicholas's editor
column17: Jamie Raab?\nThat Landon is the name of his third son?\nThat Nicholas Sparks recorded his own reading for the audio version of the novel?"}

column8: "description": "A canny young woman is struggling to survive by perpetrating various levels of mostly harmless fraud. On a rainy April morning
column9: she is reading auras at Spiritual Palms when Susan Burke walks in. A keen observer of human behavior
column10: our unnamed narrator immediately diagnoses beautiful
column11: rich Susan as an unhappy woman eager to give her lovely life a drama injection. However
column12: when the \"psychic\" visits the eerie Victorian home that has been the source of Susan's terror and grief
column13: she realizes she may not have to pretend to believe in ghosts anymore. Miles
column14: Susan's teenage stepson
column15: doesn't help matters with his disturbing manner and grisly imagination. The three are soon locked in a chilling battle to discover where the evil truly lurks and what
column16: if anything
column17: can be done to escape it.\n\"The Grownup
column18: \" originally appeared as \"What Do You Do?\" in George R. R. Martin's Rogues anthology."}

column8: "description": "Everyone knows a couple like Jack and Grace: he has looks and wealth
column9: she has charm and elegance. You'd like to get to know Grace better. But it's difficult
column10: because you realize Jack and Grace are never apart. Some might call this true love.\nPicture this: a dinner party at their perfect home
column11: the conversation and wine flowing. They appear to be in their element while entertaining. And Grace's friends are eager to reciprocate with lunch the following week. Grace wants to go
column12: but knows she never will. Her friends call--so why doesn't Grace ever answer the phone? And how can she cook such elaborate meals but remain so slim?\nAnd why are there bars on one of the bedroom windows?\nThe perfect marriage? Or the perfect lie?"}

column10: "description": "Sheryl Sandberg's Lean Inis a massive cultural phenomenon and its title has become an instant catchphrase for empowering women. The book soared to the top of bestseller lists internationally
column11: igniting global conversations about women and ambition. Sandberg packed theatres
column12: dominated opinion pages
column13: appeared on every major television show and on the cover of Time magazine
column14: and sparked ferocious debate about women and leadership.\nAsk most women whether they have the right to equality at work and the answer will be a resounding yes
column15: but ask the same women whether they'd feel confident asking for a raise
column16: a promotion
column17: or equal pay
column18: and some reticence creeps in.\nThe statistics
column19: although an improvement on previous decades
column20: are certainly not in women's favour - of 197 heads of state
column21: only twenty-two are women. Women hold just 20 percent of seats in parliaments globally
column22: and in the world of big business
column23: a meagre eighteen of the Fortune 500 CEOs are women.\nIn Lean In
column24: Sheryl Sandberg - Facebook COO and one of Fortunemagazine's Most Powerful Women in Business - draws on her own experience of working in some of the world's most successful businesses and looks at what women can do to help themselves
column25: and make the small changes in their life that can effect change on a more universal scale."}

column9: "description": "The women of the Waverley family -- whether they like it or not -- are heirs to an unusual legacy
column10: one that grows in a fenced plot behind their Queen Anne home on Pendland Street in Bascom
column11: North Carolina. There
column12: an apple tree bearing fruit of magical properties looms over a garden filled with herbs and edible flowers that possess the power to affect in curious ways anyone who eats them.\nFor nearly a decade
column13: 34-year-old Claire Waverley
column14: at peace with her family inheritance
column15: has lived in the house alone
column16: embracing the spirit of the grandmother who raised her
column17: ruing her mother's unfortunate destiny and seemingly unconcerned about the fate of her rebellious sister
column18: Sydney
column19: who freed herself long ago from their small town's constraints. Using her grandmother's mystical culinary traditions
column20: Claire has built a successful catering business -- and a carefully controlled
column21: utterly predictable life -- upon the family's peculiar gift for making life-altering delicacies: lilac jelly to engender humility
column22: for instance
column23: or rose geranium wine to call up fond memories.\nGarden Spellsreveals what happens when Sydney returns to Bascom with her young daughter
column24: turning Claire's routine existence upside down. With Sydney's homecoming
column25: the magic that the quiet caterer has measured into recipes to shape the thoughts and moods of others begins to influence Claire's own emotions in terrifying and delightful ways.\nAs the sisters reconnect and learn to support one another
column26: each finds romance where she least expects it
column27: while Sydney's child
column28: Bay
column29: discovers both the safe home she has longed for and her own surprising gifts. With the help of their elderly cousin Evanelle
column30: endowed with her own uncanny skills
column31: the Waverley women redeem the past
column32: embrace the present
column33: and take a joyful leap into the future."}

column8: "description": "'The more I know of the world
column9: the more am I convinced that I shall never see a man whom I can really love. I require so much!'\nMarianne Dashwood wears her heart on her sleeve
column10: and when she falls in love with the dashing but unsuitable John Willoughby she ignores her sister Elinor's warning that her impulsive behaviour leaves her open to gossip and innuendo. Meanwhile Elinor
column11: always sensitive to social convention
column12: is struggling to conceal her own romantic disappointment
column13: even from those closest to her. Through their parallel experience of love--and its threatened loss--the sisters learn that sense must mix with sensibility if they are to find personal happiness in a society where status and money govern the rules of love.\nThis edition includes explanatory notes
column14: textual variants between the first and second editions
column15: and Tony Tanner's introduction to the original Penguin Classic edition."}
